paragraph: CHAPTER IX. THE WALLYPUG RECOVERS HIS CROWN.
tokens: chapter wallypug recover crown

paragraph: HIS Majesty and myself stared at each other in dismay. Our position was growing more and more uncomfortable every moment, and, added to this, I had a growing impression that the rods to which we were attached would sooner or later break with our weight.
tokens: stare other dismay position grow uncomfortable moment add have grow impression rod attach break weight

paragraph: “Well! I do think that they might have helped us off the hooks, at any rate,” grumbled his Majesty, discontentedly.
tokens: think help hook rate grumble

paragraph: “So do I,” I rejoined, and was about to add something else when my attention was attracted to the peculiar behavior of the two blue birds which we had previously noticed circling about over our heads.
tokens: rejoin about add else attention attract peculiar behavior blue bird notice circle head

paragraph: They were wheeling round and round in a most eccentric manner, and as they drew closer we could see that they were as singular in appearance as they were in their manner.
tokens: wheel eccentric manner draw close see singular appearance manner

paragraph: “Why, they’ve got ever so many wings!” cried his Majesty in surprise.
tokens: get many wing cry surprise

paragraph: “Go away!” he shouted, as one of them fluttered past his face. The birds, however, were not to be got rid of so easily, and, uttering shrill little cries, they hovered about over his Majesty’s head, every now and then making a vicious dart at the sandwich which he still held in one hand.
tokens: go shout flutter face bird get rid utter shrill little cry hover head make vicious dart sandwich hold hand

paragraph: “Oh! take them away!—take them away!” he shouted, dropping his carpet-bag in alarm, and evidently forgetting that I was as incapable as he was of driving them off.
tokens: take take shout drop carpet bag alarm forget incapable drive

paragraph: “Throw your sandwich away!” I shouted; “it’s that they are after, I believe.”
tokens: throw sandwich shout believe

paragraph: His Majesty did so, and we soon had the satisfaction of seeing the birds squabbling over it on the bank at the side of the shute.
tokens: do have satisfaction see bird squabble bank side shute

paragraph: [“GO AWAY!” SHOUTED HIS MAJESTY.]
tokens: go shoute majesty

paragraph: “Fortunate I tied my bag to the string of my cloak, wasn’t it?” remarked the Wallypug, when they had gone. “I should have lost it else. Oh, look! What’s that coming down the shute?” he cried, as something suddenly came rolling and bounding down the steep incline.
tokens: fortunate tie bag string cloak remark go lose else look come shute cry come roll bound steep incline

paragraph: “O—o—o—h!” he continued delightedly, as it stopped, caught in the mouth of the carpet-bag which, attached to the cord of his Majesty’s cloak, dangled down the shute. “Why, it’s my crown! They must have thought that I wanted it, and sent it down after me. How very kind of them. Wasn’t it?”
tokens: continue stop catch mouth carpet bag attach cord cloak dangle shute crown think want send kind

paragraph: I had my own opinions on the subject, and held my peace, for I felt quite sure that it was not through any intentional kindness that the crown had found its way to its proper owner.
tokens: have own opinion subject hold peace feel sure intentional kindness crown find way proper owner

paragraph: His Majesty very carefully drew up the carpet-bag with its precious burden, and soon had the intense satisfaction of putting the crown of Why on his royal head once more.
tokens: draw carpet bag precious burden have intense satisfaction put crown royal head

paragraph: “Oh!” he cried with a little sigh of satisfaction, “it does seem nice to have it on again. I’m afraid that I should soon have caught a cold in my head, like A. Fish, Esq., if I had gone without it much longer.”
tokens: cry little sigh satisfaction seem nice have afraid catch cold head go

paragraph: [A LONG LINE OF CREATURES WAS COMING DOWN THE SHUTE.]
tokens: long line creaturr coming

paragraph: “Gracious!” he cried, pointing excitedly towards the top of the shute, “there’s something else coming down! Why it’s the Doctor-in-Law and Madame. Oh!—and the Cockatoo—and—the Rabbit and the Mole. Bless me! if the whole of Why isn’t coming along.”
tokens: gracious cry point top shute be else come bless whole come

paragraph: It was quite true; attached to a strong rope a long line of creatures was coming down the shute, the Doctor-in-Law leading the way.
tokens: true attach strong rope long line creature come shute lead way

paragraph: He soon caught sight of us dangling at the end of our rods, and calling out “Halt!” in a loud voice, he pulled at the rope as a sign that they were to stop. This signal was passed along by the others, and the Cockatoo, who was attached to the rope in a very uncomfortable manner, gave a loud “squ-a-a-k” as the sudden jerk caused it to tighten about her neck.
tokens: catch sight dangle end rod call halt loud voice pull rope sign stop signal pass other attach rope uncomfortable manner give loud squ k sudden jerk cause tighten neck

paragraph: The signal, however, managed somehow to reach those at the other end, for the procession suddenly came to a standstill.
tokens: signal manage reach other end procession come standstill

paragraph: “Oh, there you are then!” called out the Doctor-in-Law in a severe voice. “Thought you had escaped us, I suppose.”
tokens: call severe voice think escape suppose

paragraph: The Cockatoo, in a voice choking with rage, and the tightened rope, shrieked out, “Down with the traitors!” while the Rabbit passed the word along, “It’s all right. We’ve found them.”
tokens: voice choke rage tighten rope shriek traitor pass word right find

paragraph: “Just you come down and tie yourself to this rope at once!” called out Madame, glaring fiercely at the Wallypug.
tokens: come tie rope call glaring

paragraph: “Shan’t!” shouted his Majesty defiantly, pushing his crown further on to his head.
tokens: shout push crown head

paragraph: “What!” screamed the good lady, in a terrible passion. “Do you dare to rebel?”
tokens: scream good lady terrible passion dare rebel

paragraph: “Yes, I do,” called out his Majesty bravely. “I don’t believe you are my sister-in-law at all, and I’m not going back to Why to be snubbed and ill-treated for you or any one else—so there. You can’t get at me, hanging up here, and I don’t mean to get down till you’re gone. Yah!”
tokens: call believe sister law go snubb ill treat one else get hang mean get gone

paragraph: “Oh, we’ll soon see all about that,” called out the Doctor-in-Law, working himself to the edge of the shute, and trying to climb up the steep sides of the bank.
tokens: see call work edge shute try climb steep side bank

paragraph: We watched his endeavors with considerable anxiety, for if he did succeed in getting on to the bank, it would be an easy matter for him to get at us, by means of the bridge. The rope, however, by which he was attached to the Sister-in-Law was not sufficiently long to enable him to do this, and while he was unfastening it there was a sudden cry in the direction of the tunnel, and a moment afterwards, screaming, kicking, and struggling, the whole party rapidly disappeared down the shute.
tokens: watch endeavor considerable anxiety succeed get bank easy matter get means bridge rope attach long enable do unfasten be sudden cry direction tunnel moment scream kick struggle whole party disappear shute

paragraph: The rope had given way!
tokens: rope give way

paragraph: “He, he, he! Ha, ha!” laughed his Majesty, as the huddled mass vanished in the distance. “What a lark! Oh what a muddle they will be in when they reach the bottom.”
tokens: laugh huddle mass vanish distance lark muddle reach bottom

paragraph: I tried to imagine what would be the result, and came to the conclusion that, uncomfortable as I was in my present position, I would rather be where I was than attached to the rope with the others.
tokens: try imagine result come conclusion uncomfortable present position attach rope other

paragraph: In the meantime the little blue people, their curiosity evidently aroused by the noise, were hurrying towards us as quickly as possible, bringing with them a very stout blue person, who was waddling along, being alternately pushed and pulled by the others in their eagerness to reach us.
tokens: meantime little blue person curiosity arouse noise hurry possible bring stout blue person waddle push pull other eagerness reach

paragraph: “See, there they are!” cried the little lady whose name we afterwards found out was Gra-Shus. “Oh my! Aren’t they a funny color?”

paragraph: “Shall we get them down?” asked the other, whose name was Mi-Hy.

paragraph: The little fat man regarded us critically, and said nothing for a moment or two, then he nodded his head violently.

paragraph: “You’re sure you won’t bite?” said Mi-Hy, looking up into my face.

paragraph: “His Majesty the Wallypug of Why,” I explained, “wishes to say, that he hopes you are quite well.”

paragraph: [His Majesty swaggered across the bridge to where the three little blue people stood in a line to receive us.—Page 112.   _Wallypugland._]

paragraph: “Oh! I beg your pardon” said Ho-Lor. “How very stupid of me. But you know, the fact is, we get such a lot of foreigners down here, and they do ask such funny questions. A Frenchman we caught the other day actually asked me how I carried myself. Wasn’t it rude of him—considering my weight too?”

paragraph: “You’re a Wallypug, too, aren’t you?” asked Gra-Shus, looking smilingly up into my face.
tokens: ask look face

paragraph: “Oh, no!” I replied; “I am only his Majesty’s guest.”

paragraph: “His Majesty! Do you mean that?” said Mi-Hy, pointing to the Wallypug.

paragraph: The Wallypug drew himself up with an air of offended dignity.

paragraph: “I am not a ‘that’; I’m a kind of a king,” he explained, in a tone of remonstrance.

paragraph: “O-ooh!” exclaimed the little blue people, falling down on their knees and bowing their foreheads to the ground, with their hands stretched out before them. “Pray forgive us, Majestuous Wallypug, we thought you were only an ordinary person. You see we’ve never caught a king before. Oh! don’t chop our heads off, will you?”

paragraph: “Of course not,” said his Majesty, kindly.

paragraph: “Oh dear no,” said the Wallypug.

paragraph: “Get up; or you’ll spoil your clothes. Could we have a cup of tea, please? We are rather fatigued with our long journey.”

paragraph: The little blue people immediately jumped up and led the way to where behind a clump of curious blue trees the quaintest little boat you could possibly imagine was moored against the bank. A blue lake stretched as far as the eye could reach, and a number of little islands were dotted about it. On one, a little larger than the rest, a quaint little blue pagoda could be seen.
